text: On this COVID Remembrance/Memorial Day, support @MarkedByCovid Massachusetts in establishing the day. Send a letter of support to your legislators. We can't prevent what we are not willing to acknowledge. Help us remember. #CovidRemembranceDay #mapoli

On this #CovidMemorialDay, I'm revisiting this series of videos I created with the help of a few incredibly talented folks at the pandemic's peak. They offer a small window into the enormity of what we've lost and continue to lose.
They tried to save as many as they could. #CovidMemorialDay

How do you mourn the losses of over a million people? It starts with #CovidMemorialDay on Monday, March 6 at 8:00pm ET. Join @MarkedByCovid for a vigil w/ our legislative champs: Senator @ewarren and Representative @gregstantonaz For more information >> http://covidmemorialday.org/vigil

text: The good news is, it's not that hard to model empathy and compassion as a balance to the fear and anger and outrage (which I am not saying is unjustified). But we need folks to check in and see their stake in taking care of each other, not check out because it's all so bleak.

A rabbi here in Boston that was very close with my father when I was growing up, told me a few weeks before the start of the pandemic that one of America's biggest epidemics is loneliness, and I think about it everyday. It's so palpable. That will take a lot of work to repair.

There is a reason why many viral stories in our feeds are mundane moments from day to day life where someone helps an elderly neighbor cross a street or a Good Samaritan helps someone in crisis. With so much darkness, people want to feel that they're part of a community.

A reflection from 3 yrs of @FacesOfCOVID is that because much of the news people consume everyday is dripping with fear, anger, & outrage, many are desperate for reasons to give a shit about each other, & when you remind them why they should without judgement, many will respond.

text: CARL BENTON, 79, of McKinney, Texas, died of COVID on Jan. 19, 2021. My Dad was a kind and compassionate soul. He loved the Lord with all his heart. Hard worker, honest & caring. We miss him terribly. He was an active, healthy & fit 80 year old. He was not finished with life.\\""

text: I came to Twitter to grieve my mom’s death from COVID in Dec 2020. I was separated from my family, there was no service, and being immune compromised made the isolation harder. Thank you, @FacesOfCOVID , @MarkedByCovid , and #DisabilityTwitter, for helping me survive and grieve.
I want to say thank you to @FacesOfCOVID @prisonculture @SFdirewolf @BreeNewsome , you are the voices I come to Twitter for.

Hi all, I'm in the process of downloading the full @FacesOfCOVID archive in the event that Twitter does not continue to operate. For those who want to stay on my contact list if I ultimately migrate these stories to a new venue, email me at thefacesofcovid@gmail.com. - Alex
